author: ghost
body:
We have a corporate web proxy configured in our browsers, and an exception/bypass list to skip the proxy for internal sites.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47949180/75945376-af0d2600-5e5f-11ea-87a4-55a3102d423b.png)

Windows Powershell 5.x and Powershell Core 6.x honored these settings.  Invoke-WebRequest against external and internal sites used, and bypassed, the proxy respectively.  It appears that Powershell 7 reads the IE browser settings, but does not honor the exception list.

I do see the `-NoProxy` parameter works around this, but I'd rather not have to adjust scripts in this manner.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'https://internal.corp.local'
```

# Expected behavior

```none
(returned web response object)
```

# Actual behavior

```none
Invoke-WebRequest: Unable to read data from the transport connection: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host..
```
... and a network capture shows the request hitting the proxy (which, due to our network and proxy configuration, won't work).

# Environment data

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: Closing.  I had environment variables (`http_proxy`, `no_proxy`) set as well, so Powershell 7 saw those and used them instead of browser.  The syntax in `no_proxy` was bad (was using wildcards *.corp.local, need to use .corp.local).

title: Web cmdlets honor IE proxy but not exception/bypass list
